Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 01:09PM LadyB wrote: Hi Alli, I recommend that she talk to her surgeon and get a referral for occupational or physical therapy with someone familiar with mastectomy exercises.  I have the problem with cording in both arms - started 1 week post op.  It was driving me crazy.  I kept describing this pain and everyone said it was probably irritated nerves.  I am so encouraged because the therapist I saw recognized it right away and I started an exercise program that involves stretches using a pole, like a broom stick that is about 3 ft. long. I hope your mom can get some relief.  Let us know and I will post again with an update.  It wasn't even mentioned in any of the numerous books I read, but now that I know what it is called, I'm finding some references on line.  Best to you and your mom.
Posts.Title: How Many Nodes? Alli bettysgirl

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2008 03:57PM LadyB wrote: I got a reference name for "cording" from my occupational therapist.  I hope it is helpful.  Another name for cording is Axillary Web Syndrome or AWS.  I found some articles.  They make it sound like the condition will resolve by itself.  I am doing stretching exercises several times a day. They are really helping and I can tell if I don't do them.  It is always worse when I get up in the morning.  I can see that I am gaining range of motion each day.  I found a book that might help at the local library - "Thriving After Breast Cancer" by Sherry Lebed Davis.  It has many useful exercises.  My therapy is soon to end and I like having a reference guide.  You are not alone.
